channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Albania Created an ‘A.I. Minister’ to Curb Corruption. Then Its Developers Were Accused of Graft.
item.description: The Albanian avatar known as Diella, a public anticorruption crusader, has been described as the world’s first government minister created by artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Staff at Albania’s National Information Agency watching Diella, the first government minister created by artificial intelligence.

item.title: Board of Peace Set to Hand Trump Sweeping Powers Over Gaza
item.description: A draft resolution revealed some of the plans for the new international body, which met for the first time last week amid criticism from some U.S. allies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: President Trump at the Board of Peace Charter announcement at the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland, last Thursday.

item.title: How Trump’s Threats to Greenland Made Him a Liability for Europe’s Far Right
item.description: Europe’s nationalist leaders once saw President Trump as an ideological ally. Now, as he threatens European sovereignty, they are seeking distance — at least for the moment.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Koba Ryckewaert and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: President Trump leaving for the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he made a rambling speech that underscored his disdain for Europe.

item.title: All-Night Concerts in War-Ravaged Myanmar
item.description: But the shows, which combine dance, drama and music, are also part of an effort by Myanmar’s military rulers to project a veneer of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Lauren DeCicca
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times

item.title: UK Seeks Trade With China Without Triggering Trump’s Fury
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer hopes to boost his country’s lagging economy with a trip to Beijing. But he must carefully navigate between two superpowers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David Pierson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, attending a meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in 2024.

item.title: Trump Vows Higher Tariffs for South Korea Months After Trade Deal
item.description: President Trump said Seoul was not moving fast enough to implement the agreement, which calls for South Korea to invest billions in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Trump received gilded gifts from South Korea’s leader, Lee Jae Myung, when he visited the country in October.

item.title: ICE Agents Will Join Olympics Delegation in Italy. Many Italians are Angry.
item.description: The Italian government said it had requested clarification from American diplomats after D.H.S. said that ICE agents would help secure the U.S. Olympic delegation next week in northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters in Minneapolis, Minnesota, last week.

item.title: As Trump Eyes Greenland, Denmark’s Leader Is Unsure How Long U.S. Will Be an Ally
item.description: President Trump’s efforts to pry Greenland from Denmark show that “the old world order is now gone,” Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen warned in Berlin.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Danish prime minister, Mette Frederiksen, is visiting European capitals with Greenland’s leader this week, apparently seeking to shore up support for Denmark’s position in talks with the United States.

item.title: Israel Recovers Body of Ran Gvili From Gaza, Closing a Chapter
item.description: The recovery of Master Sgt. Ran Gvili’s body paves the way for the next stage of the Gaza cease-fire plan, though the path forward is unclear.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Pictures of Master Sgt. Ran Gvili at a plaza known as Hostages Square in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: As U.S. Warships Get Closer, Iran Ramps Up Threats to Retaliate
item.description: Iran and its militia allies say they will respond aggressively in the region if attacked. A U.S. aircraft carrier and warships are approaching the region.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Eric Schmitt and Hwaida Saad
item.media:description: A billboard in Enghelab Square in Tehran, threatening action against American warships.

item.title: In Venezuela, Freeing the Economy, but Nothing Else
item.description: Interim leader Delcy Rodríguez is liberalizing the economy without dismantling her predecessor’s repressive apparatus, raising questions about her aims.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Morning commuters in Caracas earlier this month.

item.title: Shift to Drone Fighting in Ukraine War Means No Winter Lull
item.description: Shifts in tactics and technology in Ukraine mean that the pace of fighting is no longer decided by whether tanks can navigate frozen fields.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers building and arming a fiber optic first-person-view, or FPV, drone last summer inside an underground bunker in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine.

item.title: Israel Says It Will Reopen Gaza-Egypt Border Crossing in Days
item.description: The Rafah crossing will open at the end of Israel’s search for the remains of the last captive in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rafah border crossing with Egypt in October 2023. Israel agreed to allow the crossing to reopen as part of the cease-fire deal struck in October.

item.title: In Xi’s China, Top General’s Fall Shows Precariousness of Power
item.description: A combat veteran, Zhang Youxia was once seen as the most trusted man in Xi Jinping’s military. Now he has been accused of disloyalty to Mr. Xi.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Zhang Youxia at a legislative meeting in Beijing in March. General Zhang was one of the commanders tapped by China’s leader to help lead his overhaul of the People’s Liberation Army.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of South Korean First Lady Kim Keon Hee
item.description: Kim Keon Hee was unlike any presidential spouse South Korea had seen. Her downfall, on corruption charges, came after her husband declared martial law.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Kim Keon Hee, South Korea’s former first lady, arrived for her first hearing on corruption charges at Seoul Central District Court in September.

item.title: Former French Senator Convicted of Drugging a Colleague, Intending to Assault Her
item.description: The trial took on special resonance in France, a year after a court found Dominique Pelicot and dozens of other men guilty of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was sedated.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Joël Guerriau, a former French senator, arriving at court with his lawyers in Paris on Monday.

item.title: How Iran Crushed an Uprising
item.description: A visual investigation by The New York Times shows the breadth and ferocity of the regime’s crackdown across the country.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Spain Offers Undocumented Migrants a Legal Way to Stay
item.description: The measure, unexpectedly approved, comes as other countries are cracking down on immigration.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Venezuelan food stall in Madrid in early January. The measure passed on Tuesday will apply to undocumented migrants already living in Spain, many of whom are from Latin America.

item.title: How Computer Warfare Is Becoming Part of the Pentagon’s Arsenal
item.description: The military tested a new approach in Venezuela and during strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The United States took power off-line in Caracas, Venezuela, to help military forces capture former President Nicolás Maduro this month.

item.title: Troop Casualties in Ukraine War Near 2 Million, Study Finds
item.description: The number of deaths, injuries and missing is approaching a grim milestone after nearly four years of fighting.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a Ukrainian soldier in Uzhhorod, Ukraine, last year. The latest accounting of casualties came after talks among Russian, Ukrainian and American officials ended on Saturday on a rare positive note.

item.title: Microsoft Pledged to Save Water. In the A.I. Era, It Expects Water Use to Soar.
item.description: Driven by the artificial intelligence frenzy, Microsoft is internally projecting that water use at its data centers will more than double by 2030 from 2020, including in places that face shortages.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Karen Weise

item.title: Trinidadian Families File Wrongful Death Lawsuit Over Boat Strike by U.S. Military
item.description: The case tests the Trump administration’s argument that its extrajudicial killings of people suspected of smuggling drugs at sea have been lawful.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: A memorial held by family members of Chad Joseph, one of two Trinidadian men whom the U.S. military apparently killed in a boat strike in the fall, in Las Cuevas, Trinidad and Tobago, in October.

item.title: Record Debt in the World’s Richest Nations Threatens Global Growth
item.description: The cost of borrowing is already choking crucial public spending in many developing economies. Now it’s raising broader alarms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Record-high debt in the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan risks slowing growth and destabilizing the global economy.

item.title: Trump Briefed on Intelligence Saying Iran’s Government Is Weaker
item.description: Protests that erupted late last year shook elements of the Iranian government, according to the reports.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A street in Tehran on Sunday. The reports signal that the Iranian government’s hold on power is at its weakest point since the shah was overthrown in the 1979 revolution.

item.title: Canada’s Marineland Whales Could Find New Homes in U.S.
item.description: Marineland, a closed aquatic park in Ontario, had threatened to euthanize its whales after the government denied an application to send them to China.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Beluga whales in November at the now-closed Arctic Cove exhibit at Marineland, in Niagara Falls, Canada.

item.title: Chinese Pandas Leave Japanese Zoo
item.description: As Japan and China feud, an animal long used in Chinese diplomacy has been summoned back home.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Visitors taking last photos of Xiao Xiao at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: NATO Chief Says Europe Is ‘Dreaming’ if It Thinks It Can Defend Itself Without U.S.
item.description: Mark Rutte, the secretary general of the alliance, told members of the European Parliament that President Trump was “doing a lot of good stuff.”
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: Secretary General Mark Rutte of NATO, right, at the European Parliament in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: Xi’s Purge of the Chinese Military
item.description: The ousting of China’s most senior general has set off fevered speculation.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: General Zhang Youxia, in 2024.

item.title: Russia Says Talks to End War in Ukraine Will Continue
item.description: Ukrainian and Russian officials left rare direct talks last weekend in a somewhat optimistic mood. But Russia may be simply stalling for time, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:description: An artillery unit of Ukraine's 59th Assault Brigade firing at Russian positions near the Ukrainian city of Pokrovsk last month.

item.title: Thousands of Flights Canceled Monday After Snowstorm
item.description: Delays and cancellations persisted a day after more than 11,000 flights were canceled. Airports in the Northeastern U.S. were hit the hardest.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi, Christine Chung, Gabe Castro-Root and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Passengers at LaGuardia Airport dealt with delays and cancellations from the storm on Sunday.

item.title: Gunmen Kill 11 After Soccer Match in Mexico
item.description: The mass shooting occurred in an area fought over by drug cartels, just as the Mexican government has sought to show Washington that it is combating criminal groups.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Mexican National Guard members at the scene where 11 people were killed in Salamanca, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: The Taliban Say They’re Ready to Release U.S. Prisoners. But Which Ones?
item.description: Top Afghan officials say they want two American detainees released “as soon as possible,” but the Trump administration says a third one should be included.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zabiullah Mujahid, the Taliban spokesman, in 2021. In a recent interview with The New York Times, he expressed the Taliban’s desire to secure the release of an Afghan inmate at Guantánamo Bay.

item.title: Winter Storm Pummels Toronto With Record Snowfall
item.description: Canada’s biggest city got roughly 22 inches, and giant snow banks are unlikely to melt soon because of colder than usual temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Toronto on Monday. The city had a record-breaking 22 inches of snow.

item.title: At Least 18 Dead After Ferry Carrying 350 Sinks in the Philippines
item.description: Two dozen people were still missing after the vessel sank early Monday morning in Basilan Province.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez

item.title: Another Fatal Shooting in Minneapolis
item.description: Events like this, where eyewitness video and independent reporting contradict the government’s account, highlight the importance of press freedom.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Federal agents confronted protesters in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: Amid Two-Week Internet Blackout, Some Iranians Are Getting Back Online
item.description: Many in Iran are gaining brief and unexplained windows of online connectivity, offering a widening glimpse of the extent of the government crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Sanam Mahoozi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tehran in October, before the internet crackdown.

item.title: In Venezuela, Families Search for Relatives Who Are Detained and Missing
item.description: Even as dozens of political prisoners have been freed, at least 66 people taken by state authorities and never heard from again remain missing, relatives and rights groups say.
item.dc:creator: Camille Rodríguez Montilla, Frances Robles and The New York Times
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How Iran Crushed a Citizen Uprising With Lethal Force
item.description: Protests erupted amid a communications blackout. But as video and witness accounts trickle out, the brutality of the regime’s crackdown is becoming clear.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi, Sanjana Varghese, Malachy Browne and Parin Behrooz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Videos and witness testimony reveal how Iran crushed a civilian uprising with lethal force.

item.title: Why Japan’s Leader Won’t Enter the Male-Dominated Sumo Ring
item.description: Sanae Takaichi, the first woman to lead Japan as prime minister, skipped a sumo awards ceremony, reflecting her cautious approach to gender issues.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: The Ukrainian Danylo Yavhusishyn, also known by his Japanese ring name, Aonishiki Arata, receiving his trophy at the New Year Grand Sumo Tournament in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: The Woman Who Stands Between Donald Trump and Greenland
item.description: Mette Frederiksen, Denmark’s leader, has taken big risks standing up to Mr. Trump. It might just be working — for now.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Denmark’s prime minister, Mette Frederiksen, in her office in Copenhagen.

item.title: The Podcaster Poking at France’s Biggest Secrets
item.description: Philippe Collin makes intricate series that are reshaping how French people understand uncomfortable parts of their history. Millions are tuning in.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Philippe Collin, a journalist, author and podcaster, recording in Paris in November.

item.title: William H. Foege, Key Figure in the Eradication of Smallpox, Dies at 89
item.description: His containment strategy helped wipe out the disease in the 1970s, one of the world’s greatest public health triumphs. He also led the C.D.C. and promoted childhood vaccination worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Keith Schneider and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: William H. Foege in 1985. He played a critical role in making smallpox the first infectious disease to be altogether eliminated. He stood beside a bust of Hygeia, the Greek goddess of health, at C.D.C. headquarters in Atlanta.

item.title: Syria Announces Cease-Fire Extension, Hours After Truce With Kurds Expired
item.description: Syria’s government and Kurdish-led forces in the country’s northeast have clashed as President Ahmed al-Sharaa seeks to extend his authority across the entire country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Kurdish-led militia fighters in northeastern Syria on Saturday. A cease-fire agreed upon with the government last Sunday called for the integration of Kurdish troops into the national army.

item.title: Trump Threatens Canada With Tariffs as Post-Davos Fallout Continues
item.description: President Trump said he would impose tariffs if Canada made “a deal with China,” though there is no sign that those countries are discussing a broad trade agreement.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on the South Lawn of the White House on Thursday, after returning from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: Ukraine Peace Talks End on Positive Note as Zelensky Teases Future Meeting
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that rare three-way negotiations between Ukrainian, Russian and American teams in Abu Dhabi had been “constructive.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Thursday in Switzerland. He said this week that he expected “at least some answers” from Russia on a draft of a peace plan.

item.title: Cold Comfort
item.description: How can the perpetually shivering warm up to winter?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Mark Carney Takes On Donald Trump and Emerges as a Global Political Star
item.description: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, the prime minister was praised for his blunt talk about the president’s irrevocable “rupture” in the world order.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney received a standing ovation for his speech at the World Economic Forum.

item.title: How a Photographer Stumbled Upon a Key Picture of the Spain Train Crash
item.description: While seeking views of the disaster, a photographer on assignment for The Times captured an image of wreckage that could provide clues to what went wrong.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The undercarriage of a train found near the crash site in Adamuz, Spain.

item.title: Despite Trump’s Words, China and Russia Are Not Threatening Greenland
item.description: U.S. and European officials say they are unaware of any intelligence that shows China and Russia are endangering the island, which is protected by the NATO security umbrella.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Trump has repeatedly cited security as his rationale for wanting to acquire Greenland.

item.title: How a Year of Trump Changed Britain
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer stood firm over Greenland. But his center-left government and the country as a whole have been buffeted by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Keir Starmer at Chequers, near London, in September during Mr. Trump’s state visit to Britain. During the debate over Greenland, Mr. Trump has had sharp words for Mr. Starmer.

item.title: How a Water Balloon Fight in Venezuela Ended in Charges of Treason
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government has been praised by President Trump. It has also maintained its state security apparatus to stamp out any perceived dissent.
item.dc:creator: Tibisay Romero, Jack Nicas, Patricia Sulbarán and The New York Times
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A 17-year-old boy who was one of 25 people detained in Barcelona, Venezuela, days after President Nicolás Maduro was captured.

item.title: Iran’s Leadership Stumbles After War and Unrest
item.description: The bloody crackdown offers hints about growing tensions inside the country’s ruling system as the cleric’s rule comes under strain.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military leaders and clerics at a ceremony in July in a Tehran mosque to mark the deaths of those killed during Israeli airstrikes in June.

item.title: Australian Boy, 12, Dies After Shark Attack Near Sydney
item.description: Nico Antic died in a hospital after a shark bit him in the legs, the first of several recent shark attacks along Australia’s southeastern coast.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Sitthixay Ditthavong/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A closed beach at Vaucluse near Sydney on Monday. Nico Antic was attacked on Sunday afternoon by what the authorities believed to have been a bull shark.

item.title: Xi’s Purge of China’s Military Brings Its Top General Down
item.description: The ouster of Gen. Zhang Youxia, who was second only to Xi Jinping in the military hierarchy, marks “the total annihilation of the high command,” one analyst said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Gen. Zhang Youxia, a vice chairman of China’s Central Military Commission, has been accused of “violations of discipline and the law,” the Ministry of National Defense said on Saturday.

item.title: An Unlikely Source of Crypto Innovation: Afghanistan
item.description: The repressive Taliban government is suspicious of the internet. But a start-up in the country is building blockchain-based tools to transform humanitarian aid.
item.dc:creator: Aryn Baker and Emile Ducke
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Local beneficiaries wait in line to receive their aid payments as part of a Mercy Corps pilot project using HesabPay, a blockchain-based payment system developed in Afghanistan, in the town of Halfaya, Syria.

item.title: What Europe Learned From the Greenland Crisis
item.description: Territorial integrity is a core tenet of Europe that is at risk from Russian and American imperialism. Brussels has fought back.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest against President Trump’s attempt to take over Greenland, in Nuuk, last week.

item.title: Russia Jails U.S. Navy Veteran for Five Years
item.description: Charles Wayne Zimmerman, who had been fulfilling his dream to sail around the world, appears to be the latest American imprisoned as part of Russia’s “hostage diplomacy.”
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Steve Witkoff, the presidential envoy who has been negotiating with the Kremlin on a peace deal in the Ukraine war, was believed to have raised the issue of incarcerated Americans during his repeated visits to Moscow.

item.title: Joint Chiefs Chairman Issues Rare Invitation to Foreign Military Heads
item.description: Top military leaders from 34 countries plan to discuss improving efforts in the Western Hemisphere to fight drug trafficking and transnational criminal organizations.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Dan Caine’s meeting comes at a fraught time for Washington’s relations with its immediate neighbors as well as allies in Europe.

item.title: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark Visits Greenland
item.description: The trip by Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen to the Danish territory came amid pressure from President Trump and appeared to have been meant as reassurance to Greenlanders.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark, in the tan coat; the mayor of Nuuk, Greenland, Avaaraq Olsenand; and Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen of Greenland set off on a highly choreographed walk through the city on Friday.

item.title: Under Pressure from Trump, Venezuela Agrees to Accept More U.S. Deportation Flights
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government, in another sign of its willingness to placate the Trump administration, is receiving more deportation flights. Three flights arrived this week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Hamed Aleaziz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A deportation flight from the United States arriving at Simón Bolívar International Airport in Venezuela on Thursday.
